facts.text: Appellant is being prosecuted under S. 7 of the Essential Commodities Act, 1955 for contravention of cls. 4 and 5 of the Iron and Steel Control Order.

anchor.surface_text: modities Act, 1955 for companytravention of cls.  4  and  5  of the Iron an-,I Steel Control Order. The prosecution was companymenced by the Inspector of Police, Crime Branch, C.I.D., Hyderabad by filing against him a charge-sheet tinder S. 173 of the Code of Criminal Procedure in respect of the offence of cheating which was intended to serve also as a report in writing of a public servant as required by S. 11 of the Essential Commodities Act, 1955.

facts.text: Prosecution commenced by the Inspector of Police, Crime Branch, C.I.D., Hyderabad by filing a charge-sheet under S. 173 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution was companymenced by the Inspector of Police, Crime Branch, C.I.D., Hyderabad by filing against him a charge-sheet tinder S. 173 of the Code of Criminal Procedure in respect of the offence of cheating which was intended to serve also as a report in writing of a public servant as required by S. 11 of the Essential Commodities Act, 1955. Learned City Magistrate of Secunderabad framed a charge against him under s. 251A 3  of the Code of Criminal Procedure in respect of both the offences.

anchor.surface_text: by filing against him a charge-sheet tinder S. 173 of the Code of Criminal Procedure in respect of the offence of cheating which was intended to serve also as a report in writing of a public servant as required by S. 11 of the Essential Commodities Act, 1955.

facts.text: Appellant raised second objection that trial under S.7 ECA should be under S.252 CrPC not S.251A.

facts.text: Sessions Judge declined to interfere in revision.

holdings.text: The meaning given by the appellant to 'police report' in s.251A CrPC as only the report under s.173 for offences investigated under Chapter XIV is incorrect; 'police report' under s.190(1)(b) means any report in writing of facts by a police officer.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the meaning which is sought to be given to a police report is number companyrect. In S. 190, a distinction is made between the classes of persons who can start a criminal prosecution. Under the three clauses of S. 190 l , to which we have already referred, criminal prosecution can be initiated  i  by a police officer by a report in writing,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.190 distinguishes classes of persons initiating prosecution; police officer's written report falls under s.190(1)(b) regardless of whether under Ch XIV or s.173.

holdings.text: The report under s.11 Essential Commodities Act by a police officer is a 'police report' under s.190(1)(b) CrPC and not a 'complaint' under s.190(1)(a) or s.4(1)(h), as complaint excludes police reports.

anchor.surface_text: In S. 190, a distinction is made between the classes of persons who can start a criminal prosecution. Under the three clauses of S. 190 l , to which we have already referred, criminal prosecution can be initiated  i  by a police officer by a report in writing,  ii  upon information received from any person other than a police officer or upon the Magistrates own knowledge or suspicion, and  iii  upon receiving a companyplaint of facts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Definition in s.4(1)(h) explicitly excludes police officer's report from 'complaint'; s.11 requires public servant report, satisfied by police officer.

holdings.text: Trial procedure under s.251A CrPC applies to offence under s.7 Essential Commodities Act when initiated by police report under s.11 that also serves as s.173 charge-sheet for s.420 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: We are thus companycerned to find out whether the report of the police officer in writing in this case can be described as a companyplaint of facts or as information received from any person other than a police officer. That it cannot be the latter is obvious enough because the information is from a police officer. The term companyplaint in this companynection has been defined by the Code of Criminal Procedure and it means the allegation made orally or in writing to a Magistrate,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Initiation by police officer's report attracts s.251A; s.252 only for non-police report cases; s.11 purpose to bar private complaints achieved.

holdings.text: A police officer investigating a cognizable offence under s.420 IPC can investigate and include in the charge-sheet a non-cognizable offence under s.7 ECA arising from the same facts without Magistrate's order under s.155(1) CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The police officer was investigating under S. 156 1  of the Code of Criminal Proce- dure an offence under s. 420, Indian Penal Code which was based on the same facts as the offence under s. 7 of the Essential Commodities Act. He investigated the latter offence along with the  1  1961 3 S.C.R. 563. former and joined it with the former in the charge-sheet which presented.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.156(2) protects joint investigation; s.155(1) applies only to solely non-cognizable cases; follows precedent in Ram Krishna Dalmia v. State.

holdings.text: Premchand Khetry v. State distinguished: where report is naturally by police officer under s.190(1)(b), full s.251A applies without needing fiction to deem it s.173 report.

anchor.surface_text: In the Calcutta A.T.R. 1958 Punj. 172. A.I.R. 1958 Cal. 213. case to which we have last referred, there was a provision  s. 20G  in the Opium Act, as amended in Bengal, which provided that a report in writing by an officer of the Excise, Police or the Customs Department shall be enquired into and tried as if such report was a report

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fiction in that case only for s.190(1)(b) cognizance, not extending to s.173/251A; here actual police investigation and report.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in not interfering in revision with the trial; appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was right in number interfering in revision with the trial of the case. We dismiss the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts correctly rejected objection to s.251A procedure and charge framing.

precedents.citation: Bhagwati Saran v. State of U.P.  1

anchor.surface_text: Bhagwati Saran v. State of U.P.  1  this Court explained the nature of a report under S. 11 of the Essential Supplies  Temporary Powers  Act, 1946 which was a provision in the same words. This Court has held that the function of the report under s. 1 1 is number to serve as a charge-sbeet against the accused, and that the purpose of s. 11 is to eliminate private individuals such as rival traders or general public from initiating the prosecution and to insist that before companynizance is taken the companyplaint must emanate from a public servant.

precedents.case_name: Bhagwati Saran v. State of U.P.
precedents.cited_proposition: Nature of report under S. 11 of Essential Supplies (Temporary Powers) Act, 1946: not a charge-sheet but to ensure initiation by public servant only
precedents.cited_holding: the function of the report under s. 11 is number to serve as a charge-sbeet against the accused, and that the purpose of s. 11 is to eliminate private individuals such as rival traders or general public from initiating the prosecution and to insist that before companynizance is taken the companyplaint must emanate from a public servant

anchor.surface_text: In Ram Krishna Dalmia v. State 1 , Falshaw J.  as he then was  observed that the provisions of s. 155 1 , Criminal Procedure Code, must be regarded as applicable to those cases where the information given to the police is solely about a number-cognizable offence. Where the information discloses a companynizable as well as a number- companynizable offence the police officer is number debarred from investigating any number-cogniz,able offence which may arise out of the same facts. He can include that number-cognizable offence in the charge-sheet which he presents for a companynizable offence. We entirely agree.

precedents.cited_proposition: Police can investigate and include non-cognizable offence in charge-sheet if arising from same facts as cognizable offence
precedents.cited_holding: the provisions of s. 155 1 , Criminal Procedure Code, must be regarded as applicable to those cases where the information given to the police is solely about a number-cognizable offence. Where the information discloses a companynizable as well as a number- companynizable offence the police officer is number debarred from investigating any number-cogniz,able offence which may arise out of the same facts. He can include that number-cognizable offence in the charge-sheet which he presents for a companynizable offence

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended before us on the authority of Premchand Khetry v. The State  2  that a prosecution under S. 25 1 A, Criminal Procedure Code can only companymence on a report under S. 173 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. ... In that case the learned Judges of the Calcutta High Court went elaborately into the meaning of the expression police report in S. 190 1  b  and held that those words were companyfined to a charge-sheet under S. 173 of the Code.

precedents.cited_proposition: Police report in s.251A means only charge-sheet under s.173; report by non-police public servant not sufficient for s.251A procedure
precedents.cited_holding: those words were companyfined to a charge-sheet under S. 173 of the Code

anchor.surface_text: In S. 190, a distinction is made between the classes of persons who can start a criminal prosecution. Under the three clauses of S. 190 l , to which we have already referred, criminal prosecution can be initiated  i  by a police officer by a report in writing,  ii  upon information received from any person other than a police officer or upon the Magistrates own knowledge or suspicion, and  iii  upon receiving a companyplaint of facts.
The High Court was right in number interfering in revision with the trial of the case. We dismiss the appeal.
